description: Borrowed from Middle French compulsion, from Late Latin compulsiō, from Latin compellere (“to compel, coerce”); see compel.

entries.meaning: An irrational need or irresistible urge to perform some action, often despite negative consequences.
examples: During the basketball game, I had a sudden compulsion to have a smoke.

entries.meaning: The use of authority, influence, or other power to force (compel) a person or persons to act.
examples: But Treaty translator and Ottawa leader Andrew Blackbird described the Treaty as made “not with the free will of the Indians, but by compulsion.”

entries.meaning: The lawful use of violence (i.e. by the administration).
